Answer: Ever heard of Crown Shyness? If not then have a look at these pictures.If you are thinking that these images have been edited, then let me tell you one thing: that these are real.Crown shynessThe effect usually occurs between trees of the same species and sometimes between different species.One theory assumes a tree's leaves can feeEver heard of Crown Shyness? If not then have a look at these pictures.If you are thinking that these images have been edited, then let me tell you one thing: that these are real.Crown shynessThe effect usually occurs between trees of the same species and sometimes between different species.One theory assumes a tree's leaves can feel when they are approaching another tree. Once they sense a nearing neighbor, the growing process halts, ensuring that light can penetrate the canopy and photosynthesis continue.Another possible explanation is that this is a defense mechanism against leaf-eating insects. The gaps mean bugs wouldn't be able to reach other trees, impeding their spread.The next time you're out walking through the forest, take a moment to look above you and you might be pleasantly surprised by what you find.Edit 1: Thanks Robert Taylor for the correction.Edit 2: Thank you all for your love, affection, and kind comments.

Answer: My last paper presentation to a technology conference in ’98 was laughed off podium. To be fair, I was asked to do it to give a red-herring to a competing graphics group. I did a presentation on terrains, they implemented my terrains. I did a presentation on round-earth geometry, they went from flat to round earth (which for the age was remarkable). I was asked in a hallway about my math, I admitted to using quaternions, they researched and implemented quaternions.You’d think I would learn to keep my mouth shut, except … they were government and I was contractor, I am not allowed to lie to theMy last paper presentation to a technology conference in ’98 was laughed off podium. To be fair, I was asked to do it to give a red-herring to a competing graphics group. I did a presentation on terrains, they implemented my terrains. I did a presentation on round-earth geometry, they went from flat to round earth (which for the age was remarkable). I was asked in a hallway about my math, I admitted to using quaternions, they researched and implemented quaternions.You’d think I would learn to keep my mouth shut, except … they were government and I was contractor, I am not allowed to lie to them. I am not allowed to tell them, “no.” They even clarified that with the general when my boss tried to make sure I could refuse them. They wanted free flow of informationWhen my boss loss the toss from the general on the denial of free flow of information, he wanted me to … lie.I can can’t count the number of times I have been asked to predict the future. It’s a part of my job, per se. People have made million dollar plus decisions based on it. They are educated guesses, but they are based on the course of technology.Distant is good. Make it sound like we need to prepare for it because the technology will be shifting and therefore core skills will be shifting or something.So I did a presentation in 1998 where I discussed massively cored processors requiring new language and parallel skills the like of which the industry, even High Performance Computing has not seen. I discussed the shift of the GPU to compete against large scale computing clusters. And finally I talked about ray-tracing on the GPU arriving somewhere on the scale of 15–20 years. In order to get there, we had to go through the other technologies. We had to have programs loaded onto the GPU to speed up the processes: new languages, new techniques.This means a complete revolution in computer graphics over 20 years that nothing would be recognizable compared to the graphics of “today.” (back then)In 1999 the core splits on the GPU began. They were simple shared function splits. In 2001 the GeForce 3 introduced shading languages and programmability to the GPU. I’ve been playing with the large scale GPU High Performance Computing capability for the last few years for my Bachelor’s degree. The final Theme of the paper, what I said was 15–20 years away in 1998…NVIDIA GeForce RTX 20 Series Graphics Cards2019

Answer: I'm so surprised that there are so many interesting answers that hardly touch on what seems to me the obvious answer.The Enlightenment, starting about 300 years ago, was a tectonic shift in human development.   Plenty of brilliant people made connections and developed coherent understandings of how things in the world worked before then.  But the idea that you ought to go the other way - try to disprove things rather than prove them. Tie hypotheses to theories and come up with experiments to prove them wrong.  Eliminate variables.  Publish results and methods so that others can try.This metI'm so surprised that there are so many interesting answers that hardly touch on what seems to me the obvious answer.The Enlightenment, starting about 300 years ago, was a tectonic shift in human development.   Plenty of brilliant people made connections and developed coherent understandings of how things in the world worked before then.  But the idea that you ought to go the other way - try to disprove things rather than prove them. Tie hypotheses to theories and come up with experiments to prove them wrong.  Eliminate variables.  Publish results and methods so that others can try.This method didn't do much for religion or philosophy or ethics, but it did a hell of a lot for science.  As it gained steam, it provided a reliable, scientific basis for advances in technology.   People built bridges before the Enlightenment, but if they tried to build one differently than the ones that were already up, there was a good chance it would fall down.  But with the physics to understand materials and the math to manipulate the physics, you could design a different kind of bridge that you knew in advance would not fall down.There were ingenious technologies and great technical achievements before the Enlightenment, but until this current tick of human history, there was never a large and growing and accessible body of theory to enable new technology.

Answer: Back in the 1980s I worked on the first microprocessor version of the VAX minicomputer line at Digital Equipment. The first VAX, the 11/780, was released in 1977 and occupied several refrigerator-sized racks. The ace consultantThey handed out these models to team members, and I have one myself. There’s an Ethernet coming out of it and a serial port for a terminal. The Pi Zero takes 1500X less power and occupies 90,000X less volume!EvBack in the 1980s I worked on the first microprocessor version of the VAX minicomputer line at Digital Equipment. The first VAX, the 11/780, was released in 1977 and occupied several refrigerator-sized racks. The ace consultantThey handed out these models to team members, and I have one myself. There’s an Ethernet coming out of it and a serial port for a terminal. The Pi Zero takes 1500X less power and occupies 90,000X less volume!Even though the last VAX hardware shipped in 2000, their binary software images are still run on emulators like this. You can still buy quite powerful VAXen - they’re just emulators running on x86es. They interface with all the old peripherals at the same timings. The completely weightless binaries have outlasted the tens of thousands of tons of steel, copper, and silicon that made the original machines! More here:

Answer: yes, it is indeed rediculous“unimaginable level” is per definition “unimaginable” - so what are you expecting from us?“distant future” is how distant exactly?but ok. there are not so many supermassive black holes. one per galaxy. why only one? well, if there are two or more in a galaxy, in the distant future they will be merged into one. heavy objects tend to concentrate in the middle and black holes in a galaxy are no exception.how fast is the jet gas? if it is an inactive supermassive black hole (aka an “old” galaxy), the jet gas is not existing. so we will assume a speed of zero. if it is ayes, it is indeed rediculous“unimaginable level” is per definition “unimaginable” - so what are you expecting from us?“distant future” is how distant exactly?but ok. there are not so many supermassive black holes. one per galaxy. why only one? well, if there are two or more in a galaxy, in the distant future they will be merged into one. heavy objects tend to concentrate in the middle and black holes in a galaxy are no exception.how fast is the jet gas? if it is an inactive supermassive black hole (aka an “old” galaxy), the jet gas is not existing. so we will assume a speed of zero. if it is an active supermassive black hole, the jet gas is highly energtic and destroyes everything in its way. but it is quite fast - but strictly sub-luminal.the nearest supermassive black hole from earth is 30 000 light years away. but this one (the one in our galaxy) is inactive and has no jets. of course we could push some stars into the hole to activate it. then it would have two nice jets. and then what? it would take an incredible amount of work/energy to get there - but only to be able to travel with sub-luminal speeds in a specific direction? it would be a quite impractical propulsion system.but hey - we are talking about “unimaginable level” and “distant future”. of course - when we have warp drives with infinite speed, the travel time to the nearest active black hole is zero. and then we will have technology to let the spacecraft survive the energy of the jet. and i am sure that some dumb kids of super rich people will love to “surf on the jet” for no other reason as to brag about it with other dumb kids.

question: https://www.quora.com/What-are-the-mind-blowing-facts-depicting-how-computer-technology-has-evolved-tremendously-in-relatively-short-span-of-time

Answer: The typical response to the question “Do you think that people are that smart to create the technology we have today or do you believe its possible that a higher intelligence shared this with us at some point to help us evolve” is the [Ayn] Randian notion of the lone genius creating technology and bringing it to the rest of humanity, who would not even be able to take a piss without someone holding their dick for them.And it’s nonsense. The invention of technology has always been a group effort, requiring the work of many. All the technology we see today is the result of incremental improvemenThe typical response to the question “Do you think that people are that smart to create the technology we have today or do you believe its possible that a higher intelligence shared this with us at some point to help us evolve” is the [Ayn] Randian notion of the lone genius creating technology and bringing it to the rest of humanity, who would not even be able to take a piss without someone holding their dick for them.And it’s nonsense. The invention of technology has always been a group effort, requiring the work of many. All the technology we see today is the result of incremental improvement of past technologies by humans working together. So where does this notion of the lone hero genius inventor come from?It comes from a historical tradition; in the West, starting with the Greeks and Prometheus, who is said to have been a Titan, one of the twelve children of the primordial parents Uranus (Sky) and his mother, Gaia (Earth).The story goes that Prometheus stole fire from the rest of the Titanic gods, brought it to humanity, and was punished for his generosity by being chained to a rock and having an eagle come daily to peck out his liver and eat it. His liver would magically regenerate in the evening, and the whole cycle would be repeated the next day, one assumes, for eternity.In the Western classical tradition, Prometheus became a figure who represented human striving, particularly the quest for scientific knowledge, and the risk of overreaching or unintended consequences. In particular, he was regarded in the Romantic era as embodying the lone genius whose efforts to improve human existence could also result in tragedy: Mary Shelley, for instance, gave The Modern Prometheus as the subtitle to her novel Frankenstein.Let’s look at that first, original technology: fire, without which no other subsequent technologies would have been possible.Fire was not invented by some lone genius; had that been the case, humanity would have died out long before even reaching the stage of Homo erectus, much less Homo sapiens.The discovery of fire (note the word “discovery”, rather than “invention”) was probably a fortuitous stroke of luck. Lightning had probably struck some trees and set them on fire, and a group of curious humans noted its warmth, and its capacity to turn darkness into light, and how much better the burnt, cooked animals who were unfortunate enough to cross its path tasted (and were more nutritious and easier to digest).The discovery of fire was a group effort; so was the capacity to create it, rather than just stumble upon it fortuitously.The ability to make fire was discovered separately, many times, by many different species of humans over eons of time over the entire globe. Many different methods were invented, such as rubbing a stick against a platform of wood, creating friction and heat, which would set fire to dry moss or grasses. Other technologies employed nothing more complex than flint banged against other rocks, causing sparks which could then set alight kindling. Over the millennia, the technology has not changed much; a butane lighter produces flame by scratching metal against ferrocerium, the modern-day version of flint, igniting pressurized butane gas.Bringing us up to the present, one of the greatest inventors in history, Thomas Edison, at one point had hundreds of scientists and engineers working for him on various projects in teams; do you really think he invented the gramophone, the light bulb, and the telegraph all by himself?Edison, in fact, invented none of these technologies; most of them already existed and had been invented some time before by others. Edison merely improved them and made them commercially viable, and he needed a veritable army of engineers and scientists to do so.If you really want to talk about a “lone genius,” Nikola Tesla would be most appropriate, since he worked mostly alone, with perhaps an assistant or two, and came up with some truly original technologies, the A\C induction motor among them (which had already been invented by someone else, so even THAT is not a technology sui generis).The invention of technology is and has always been a group effort from the beginning. The idea of the lone genius is politely called a “myth.”A better, perhaps more vulgar, but more accurate term, would be “bullshit.”
name: Colleen Farrelly

Answer: A higher intelligence absolutely created our technology.But it was not alien or divine.You see right within the human species there is variability. A tiny fraction of all humans is responsible for everything we call technology. That tiny fraction is definitely more intelligent than the average human.To compound that further, most modern “inventions” are just a little further step added onto concepts and using tools devised by previous generations. (So a current genius using tools and concepts from hundreds of other geniuses.) Having calculators and computers also allows us to buy extra IQ forA higher intelligence absolutely created our technology.But it was not alien or divine.You see right within the human species there is variability. A tiny fraction of all humans is responsible for everything we call technology. That tiny fraction is definitely more intelligent than the average human.To compound that further, most modern “inventions” are just a little further step added onto concepts and using tools devised by previous generations. (So a current genius using tools and concepts from hundreds of other geniuses.) Having calculators and computers also allows us to buy extra IQ for making cool stuff.Collectively that adds up to some pretty amazing intelligence.The average human being would not even be able to make stone age tools if left to their own devices and raised without technology and trained in math, etc. True story.If they had to invent all their technology on their own they would probably be at the sharpening stick stage.
